Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on . Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or
at the time specified in this rule:

(h) A statement from the employee regarding
any convictions.
One of nine new employee files reviewed did not have an employee's written
statement explaining their criminal conviction.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are
obtained prior to employment from persons
unrelated to the employee and which are less
than 12 months old.
Two of nine new employee files reviewed had three references, but they were not
dated. One of nine new employee files reviewed had three references, but one
was completed by someone related to the employee.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

(11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective

Seclusions from 9/1/24-10/11/24 were reviewed and did not fall under the
parameters approved in the facility's variance approval letter for this rule.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:

• The facility needs to develop a clear way to show verification staff are signing off
that they received their job description.
• The facility needs to develop a clear way to show the relationship of the person
giving a candidate a reference to ensure they're not related to the candidate.
• The facility's fire extinguishers expired in September 2024; however, the Quality
Fire Inspector was scheduled to come out 10/18/24. In the future, the facility
should ensure they set reminders for when the extinguishers expire to ensure
they're taken care of timely.
• If a youth is removed from a group setting as a form of intervention and placed in
another locked room or area, staff must be in the room with the youth for it not to
be considered seclusion.
• Seclusions must follow the parameters of the variance approval letter. In
addition, seclusion records must include all interventions completed with the
youth prior to a seclusion occurs.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency did not require any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The facility had one incident of maltreatment, which was investigated under
SIR #2024SIC0001182 (dated 9/19/24). The facility was found in violation of Rule
4112(4)(a). The CAP was approved on paper, but needs to be inputted, and
approved in CWLM. As a part of the investigation, the facility complied with law
enforcement, complied with DCWL, suspended a staff's access to the facility and
juveniles, and subsequently fired the staff.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
facility had one CAP as a result of their 2023 Interim Inspection. The violations
were related to Rule 4112(1)(b) Central Registry Clearance, Rule 4113(1)(e)
References, 4113(1)(g) Agency evaluation for employee's criminal convictions,
4113(1)(j) Performance Evaluations, and 4166(a) & 4116(f) related to Discharge
Plans. In order to address these violations, the facility developed and used a new
hire checklist, and the team leader is ensuring the location and who the youth was
discharged to is located in the youth's file.
Financial Overview

There were no concerns based on review of the facility’s financial audit and
budget.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported things are going well at the facility, but they are
ready for construction to be finished, so they can resume normal functioning. CA
reported developing the new hire checklist for new employee files has helped
significantly with ensuring their employee files meet licensing requirements.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported there's good communication regarding training, policy changes,
procedure changes, etc. as the facility posts them online as well as updates the
board. Staff reported youth specialists support each other very well and
supervisors support all the staff as well. Staff reported it's a great environment and
a great place to work. Staff reported the only things they would like to see improve
are:
- Having more meetings with the whole team, so everyone is on the same
page rather than just having those meetings during shift changes.
- Construction to be finished because it's been difficult not having the use
of the entire building and not being able to go outside due to the safety
concerns.
- Some double standards for staff exist likely due to relationships or
seniority, which causes some morale problems.
Youth reported they are well fed, but the food quality could be improved. Youth
reported staff are good and staff treat them well. Youth reported they feel safe at
the facility and have staff to talk to if they feel unsafe. Youth reported the only
complaint is not being able to go outside due to the safety issues surrounding the
building construction.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility was completed on October 11, 2024. There were no
concerns for the parts of the facility currently in use. Some parts of the facility were
not able to be viewed due to the ongoing construction occurring. However, a
walkthrough of Phase 1 construction was completed. Although it is not ready for
occupancy yet, progress has continued to be made, and it is hopeful they'll be able
to begin using the new phase within the next couple months.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
